CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing)
JUDGES: Guido Raimondi;Helen Keller;Ineta Ziemele;Paulo Pinto De Albuquerque
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in LOC .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant approached ORG of ORG for a determination of whether she could become the legal guardian of her grandson , J.B. The Government specified that the ORG had provided the applicant with the information requested , but the applicant had never submitted an official application for guardianship .

CARDINAL . On DATE , who did not possess a driver ’s licence , was driving a car and caused a car accident . As a consequence , the applicant ’s grandson PERSON , who had been a passenger in the car , died from his injuries . He was DATE . CARDINAL other passengers were seriously hurt .

CARDINAL . The applicant was granted the status of a victim in criminal proceedings in respect of PERSON When being questioned by an investigator on DATE , she stated that she did not speak the NORP language . On DATE , the applicant submitted a civil claim which was written in NORP and translated by a translator from a police station . She claimed CARDINAL NORP litai ( LTL ) in respect of pecuniary damage , listing expenses which she had incurred in connection with her grandson ’s funeral . The applicant also claimed LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL in respect of non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG , following criminal proceedings , found PERSON guilty of dangerous driving which had resulted in the death of a person ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ) . He was sentenced to DATE imprisonment , but the execution of the sentence was suspended for DATE . The court did not pronounce on whether PERSON had been driving while intoxicated .

During the hearing , where the applicant , an interpreter , PERSON and his lawyer were present , the applicant asked that LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL be awarded to her in compensation for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage . The prosecutor asked the court to grant the request . PERSON stated that he could pay the applicant LTL CARDINAL each month .
The criminal court left the applicant ’s civil claim to be examined in separate civil proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant instituted civil proceedings , claiming LTL CARDINAL for pecuniary and LTL CARDINAL for non - pecuniary damage . She stated that before his death her grandson had lived with her , as his mother lived in GPE and his father had another family . PERSON ’s death had caused the applicant severe emotional distress . In the applicant ’s understanding , the criminal court had already awarded her the sum of LTL CARDINAL in disposing of the criminal proceedings . She noted that although DATE had passed since the car accident , PERSON had not paid her the money . The applicant also referred to the possibility that , in the event that PERSON was in a difficult financial situation , compensation for the damage she had sustained might be paid to her in several instalments rather than as a lump sum .
The Government have provided the ORG with an invoice from a law firm to the effect that on DATE the applicant paid LTL CARDINAL for “ legal services ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant presented the court with an estimate of her loss in connection with her grandson ’s death . She claimed LTL CARDINAL in total . That sum consisted of LTL CARDINAL for pecuniary damage , which included a detailed calculation of her grandson ’s burial costs , and LTL CARDINAL in compensation for non - pecuniary damage .
CARDINAL . NORP In a written response PERSON asked the court to grant the claim in part and to award the applicant LAW .

CARDINAL . Seeing the potential for the parties to reach a friendly settlement , on DATE the judge held a preliminary hearing . The applicant , an interpreter , PERSON and his lawyer were present . As is evident from the transcript of the hearing , after the judge had explained the parties’ rights to them , the applicant asked the court to include a calculation of her expenses in the case file . PERSON ’s lawyer , without making any other observations or statements , asked that documents concerning PERSON ’s salary and family situation also be included in the file . Both requests were granted .

When asked to present her arguments and claims on the merits , the applicant stated that during the criminal proceedings she , the prosecutor , PERSON and his lawyer had agreed that PERSON would pay her LTL CARDINAL in compensation under both heads . However , PERSON had paid nothing so far . The applicant argued that her financial situation was not good . She had no further requests .
PERSON acknowledged the civil claim in part , but stated that the sum of LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL was too high .
The court held that the case should be decided following a court hearing with the participation of the parties and an interpreter .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent the court a letter , raising the claim for compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage by LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL and requesting that she be awarded LTL CARDINAL in total under that head . She noted that her family had been suffering for DATE and implied that no steps towards reconciliation had been taken on PERSON ’s part .

CARDINAL . According to the transcript of the Šalčininkai District Court hearing of DATE , the applicant , an interpreter and the lawyer for PERSON took part in that hearing . It was also noted that the judge had explained the parties’ rights to them and that the parties understood them . The judge also asked the parties to put forward any requests , if they had any . The applicant asked the court to include her modified compensation claim in the case file . Given that the other party did not object , the judge accepted the modified claim .

When hearing the case on the merits , the applicant again explained to the court that during the criminal proceedings the parties had come to an oral agreement that PERSON would pay her LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL , but to that day he had paid nothing . She presented a very detailed calculation of her expenses , based on invoices , for her grandson ’s funeral and headstone construction costs . All in all , the applicant asked the court to award her the sum of LTL CARDINAL in compensation for pecuniary damage and LTL CARDINAL in compensation for non - pecuniary damage .

The lawyer for PERSON acknowledged that , given that her client had already been found guilty in criminal proceedings , only the question of damages remained . She also accepted that the applicant had suffered non - pecuniary damage because of her grandson ’s death . That being so , the lawyer asked the court to grant the applicant ’s civil claim in part and to award her payment of the costs which were justified by invoices . As to non - pecuniary damage , the lawyer asked the court to make an award which would be reasonable and fair , taking into account the economic situation in GPE and the fact that PERSON only had a low salary and had no other property .
The judge noted that the court ’s decision would be announced on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted the applicant ’s claim in part . The court took notice of PERSON ’s conviction for dangerous driving and held that , consequently , it was not necessary to prove his liability in the civil proceedings . PERSON was ordered to fully compensate the pecuniary damage he had caused to the applicant by her grandson ’s death . Having had regard to the documents before it , the court awarded the applicant LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL in compensation for pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . As to non - pecuniary damage , the Šalčininkai ORG took note of the applicant ’s claim that the loss of her grandson had caused her great mental suffering . For the court , it was nonetheless important to point out that the car accident had been caused by PERSON ’s recklessness , and not deliberately . It was also relevant that PERSON was relatively poor : he had a job but his salary was low ( the court did not specify the level of salary in the decision ) , and he had no other property or income . Moreover , PERSON was a young person , therefore “ the amount of compensation was not to ruin his life ” . Relying on the above arguments , ORG awarded the applicant LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL in compensation for non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , arguing that the award of damages was too low and asking that the case be remitted to the first - instance court for fresh examination , “ in accordance with LAW . She submitted , with references to specific provisions of that LAW , that the first - instance court had breached the principle of adversarial proceedings , the principle of the parties’ procedural equality and a person ’s right to State legal aid . The applicant argued that she , as a LANGUAGE - speaking person of old age and little education , had not been able to properly exercise her rights at the hearing and effectively assert her claim . Neither had she been able to effectively support her claim by evidence .

CARDINAL . In her appeal , the applicant also wrote that the judge hearing her case at ORG , just before the preliminary hearing concerning her claim and without noting it down in the transcript , had suggested to her that she find a lawyer . According to the applicant , the lawyer she approached had asked her to pay LTL CARDINAL for legal services . The applicant had no such money and had therefore had to represent herself before the court of first instance . According to her , the same lawyer in fact had represented PERSON before the court . Only after the first - instance court had adopted the decision on the merits had the applicant found out that she had had the right to free legal aid , paid for by the ORG . In her view , had she had a lawyer , she would have been in a much better position to defend her interests and to obtain a court decision that would have fulfilled her expectations .

CARDINAL . The appeal hearing before ORG took place on DATE , in the presence of the applicant and an interpreter . Neither PERSON nor his lawyer took part in that hearing , although PERSON had been informed of its date . As is evident from the transcript of the hearing , after the presiding judge explained the applicant ’s rights to her , the applicant asked the court to admit in evidence CARDINAL documents about her and her husband ’s state of health . The request was granted . The applicant also submitted that she and her husband had been raising their grandson , PERSON , as of DATE . After his death , there was no one to help them in the household . The applicant asked the court to grant her civil claim on the basis of the submissions that she had already made in writing .

CARDINAL . By a ruling of DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . The court noted that at hearings on DATE and DATE the first - instance court had explained the applicant ’s procedural rights to her , in the presence of an interpreter , and that the applicant had understood those rights . There was no information in the case file leading to the conclusion that ORG had breached the rules of civil procedure or the principles mentioned by the applicant . The court held that the applicant ’s suggestion that her claim would have been fully granted if she had had a lawyer was unfounded , as a lawyer ’s participation in proceedings could not guarantee a favourable outcome . Moreover , the fact that PERSON had been represented by a lawyer with whom the applicant had failed to conclude an agreement to represent her did not affect the lawfulness and fairness of the decision the first - instance court had adopted .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that before the accident , the applicant ’s grandson PERSON had lived with her for DATE and had often helped her , and that she had indeed lost the opportunity to communicate with him and to receive help from him . Nonetheless , the compensation award of LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL for non - pecuniary damage which the first - instance court had made was reasonable . The lower court had also been correct in taking into account the fact that the applicant ’s grandson had died because of PERSON ’s recklessness and not because of a premeditated crime , as well as PERSON ’s difficult financial situation . Lastly , ORG found that the written evidence about the applicant ’s state of health that she had submitted to the appellate court did not give grounds to annul the first - instance court ’s decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted an appeal on points of law , drafted by a lawyer . She reiterated her argument that because she was a LANGUAGE - speaking person of old age , poor health and with little education , she had been unable to protect her interests properly in court without professional legal assistance . The applicant drew ORG attention to its ruling of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , arguing that the lower courts should have taken the above factors into account . She also argued that the lower courts had wrongly established that PERSON had caused the car accident merely by not being careful . In the applicant ’s view , PERSON had been openly reckless : he had had no driving licence and had been speeding . She did not argue that PERSON had been driving drunk . The applicant asked ORG to grant her civil claim in full and to award her the money she had paid for legal representation .
PERSON did not lodge a response to the applicant ’s appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG , in written proceedings , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on points of law . It noted that non - pecuniary damage was always to be compensated when a loss of life had occurred because of a crime . In this case , PERSON had not questioned his liability , the dispute thus concerning only the sum to be awarded in compensation for non - pecuniary damage . ORG also observed that the applicant ’s grandson had died not because of PERSON ’s premeditated actions , but because of his being reckless when driving and violating traffic rules . The lower courts had taken all the circumstances into account when assessing the amount of compensation . It was also noteworthy that the award of LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL was close to the initial sum that the applicant had asked for in bringing the claim on DATE . Only later had she raised that claim by LTL CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Should ORG raise the amount of compensation , it would mean re - evaluating the facts of the case de novo , and this was not within the competence of that court .
ORG did not pronounce on the applicant ’s claim that she had not been in a position to effectively defend her interests before the first - instance and appellate courts .

NORP In response to a request for information by the Government , on DATE ORG wrote that people living in the municipality are informed of free legal aid via a local newspaper , published in both the NORP and NORP languages . They can also obtain leaflets on the subject at the council ’s offices . Lastly , information about free legal aid is presented on billboards at ORG . CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure ( hereinafter DATE “ the ORG ” ) provides that court proceedings are conducted in the country ’s official language , that is , NORP ( LAW ) . Civil proceedings are adversarial and each party must prove the facts it relies upon ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Practice direction no . CARDINAL of ORG reads as follows :

“ ... The limits of a civil claim are defined by the ... entirety of the material legal basis [ for the claim ] indicated to the court ( the subject of the claim ) and by the evidence with which the requirements [ of the law ] are fulfilled ( the factual basis of the claim ) . Since , according to LAW ORG , only the plaintiff has the right to change the subject or the basis of the civil claim , [ or ] to increase or decrease the claim , the court when adopting a procedural decision may not overstep the limits of the civil claim ; i.e. may not change the subject of the civil claim ( the court may not adjudge something that was not requested by the plaintiff ( extra petita ) or adjudge a higher amount than was requested ( ultra petita ) , nor change the basis of the civil claim ( in its decision the court can not rely on facts that were not indicated by the plaintiff or evidence that the case file does not contain ) ( LAW ORG ) ) . ”
CARDINAL . ORG ruling of DATE in civil case no . ORG reads as follows :

“ ... The principle of equality of arms has an immediate connection with the fundamental principles of civil proceedings – those of adversarial proceedings and control of the litigation by the parties ( dispozityviškumas ) . It has been established by the ORG that all civil cases in all courts shall be examined in accordance with the principle of adversarial proceedings . This m , only assesses the evidence , establishes the responses are based . The court thus does not examine facts or collect evidence on its own initiative , but has to explain the parties’ rights to them and equally assist them in exercising those rights when the parties are in need of such assistance ( for example , to obtain certain evidence on a party ’s request , when that party does not have access to such evidence ) . The court however is not entitled to take the side of CARDINAL of the parties and help [ that party ] to collect evidence , as in such a case not only would the principle of adversarial proceedings , but also the principles of equality of arms and impartiality of the court be violated ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , when assessing the pecuniary damage a claimant had sustained as a consequence of her injury during a car accident , noted that the claimant ’s personality , age and state of health were circumstances to be taken into consideration when assessing her capacity to collect and present evidence ( ruling in civil case no . CARDINALK-CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . On the issue of explaining the parties’ rights , in its ruling of DATE in civil case no . ORG held :

“ ... The courts are bound by the ORG to explain to the persons taking part in the proceedings their rights and obligations ... Such [ an ] obligation on the court , however , does not mean that the court is bound to indicate what specific requests a party should submit or what specific means of defence against a civil claim a party should use in a particular case ... ”

CARDINAL . If the presiding judge considers that a party to civil proceedings is incapable of adequately protecting its rights , he or she may suggest that that party obtain legal representation ( LAW ORG ) .

CARDINAL . According to LAW of the ORG , in civil proceedings it is not necessary to prove de novo facts that have been proved in criminal proceedings in which a court judgment has entered into force .
An appellate court may quash the first - instance court ’s decision in part or in its entirety and refer the case for fresh examination ( LAW ) .
An appeal on points of law must be drafted by a lawyer ( LAW ) . The court reviewing such an appeal is bound by the facts established by lower courts and may only decide questions of law ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Free legal aid is regulated by ORG . It is provided by , inter alia , ORG - funded legal aid services ( “ Services ” ) , municipal authorities and ORG . Each municipal authority and ORG must regularly inform local residents about the possibility of receiving free legal aid . The law defines CARDINAL categories of legal aid . Primary legal aid , that is the provision of legal information , legal advice , and drafting of documents to be submitted to municipal authorities and ORG institutions , is provided for at the municipal level . When a person wishes to receive secondary legal aid , which consists of drafting procedural documents and representation in court , he or she must address the ORG of that court ’s geographical area and prove his or her eligibility , which depends on the individual ’s financial means .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , a person who has caused a car accident that has resulted in the death of a person may be punished by deprivation of liberty for DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides that pecuniary loss resulting from any bodily or property damage caused to another person and also , in cases established by the law , non - pecuniary damage must be fully compensated by the person liable .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , non - pecuniary damage is deemed to be a person ’s suffering , emotional distress , inconvenience , mental shock , emotional depression , diminution of the chance to associate with others , and so on , as evaluated by a court in monetary terms . Non - pecuniary damage is to be compensated in all cases where it has occurred due to crime , injury to health or loss of life , as well as in other cases provided for by law . In assessing the amount of non - pecuniary damage , a court must take into consideration the consequences of such damage sustained , the extent to which the person who caused the damage was at fault , his financial status and any other circumstances of importance for the case , in addition to the criteria of good faith , fairness and reasonableness .
